Behavioral Factors

Download a PDF of all Behavioral Factors studies

Narrowing the treatment gap with equitable access: Mid-term outcomes of a community case management program in Cameroon

Littrell M, Moukam LV, Libite R, Youmba JC, Baugh G
Health Policy and Planning, 2013, 28 (7): 705-716
Location East region of Cameroon
Population Households with children under 5
Intervention Description Community case management for childhood ilnesses. CCM package providedcommunity-based diagnosis, treatment and referral for suspectedmalaria with artemisinin combination therapy (ACT)and diarrhoeal disease with ORS and zinc through community health workers (PSI)
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Awareness, access, and attitudes towards CHWservices among caregivers improved with intervention

Behaviors: Children living in intervention vs comparisonareas were significantly more likely to receive treatmentat a public health facility or through a CHW for fever and diarrheaAppropriate treatment was significantly higher among childrenin intervention vs comparison areas including: antimalarialtreatment for fever , ACTfor fever , ORS fordiarrhea and zinc fordiarrhea
Design Quasi-experimental
Sampling Method Purposive
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 2: Behavior, Method mix

Addressing inequities in access to health products through the use of social marketing, community mobilization, and local entrepreneurs in rural western Kenya

Harris JR, Patel MK, Juliao P, Suchdev PS, Ruth LJ, Were V, Ochieng C, Faith SH, Kola S, Otieno R, Sadumah I, Obure A, Quick R
International Journal of Population Research, 2012, ID 470598
Location Western Kenya
Population Households in 60 villages in Western Kenya
Intervention Description Social marketing of Water Guard water reatment products, Sprinkles, and insecticide-treated bednets through Safe Water and AIDS project vendors
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: At FU1, greater proportions of respondents from intervention households than comparison households who received SWAP vendor visits reported purchasing WaterGuard (14% versus 2%, P < 0.0001), ITNs (3% versus 1%, P < 0.04), andSprinkles (36% versus 6%, P < 0.0001) from SWAP vendors
Design Experimental
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 6
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Exchange, Segmentation, Methods mix

Evaluation of a social marketing intervention promoting oral rehydration salts in Burundi

Kassegne S, Kays MB, Nzohabonayo J
BMC Public Health, 2011, 11 (155): 1-13
Location Burundi
Population Females of reproductive age in 30 households from each of the 115 "collines" in Burundi
Intervention Description PSI led this social marketing intervention to promote the use of ORASEL for children under five. Campaign included mass media promotion and community outreach (PSI)
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Positive changes in behavioral determinants associated with ORASEL use

Behaviors: ORASEL use among caregivers at their children’s last diarrheal episode increased significantly from 20% in2006 to 30% in 2007
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 5:Behavior Customer orientation, Insight, Theory, Mixed methods

National Scale-up of Zinc Promotion in Nepal: Results from a Post-project Population-based Survey

Wang W, MacDonald VM, Paudel M, Banke KK
Journal of Health, Population, and Nutrition, 2011, 29 (3): 207-217
Location 30 focus districts in Nepal
Population Households surveys with children under 6 years of age
Intervention Description The Social Marketing Plus for Diarrhoeal Disease Control: Point of Use WaterDisinfection and Zinc Treatment (POUZN) project; Survey regarding knowledge and beliefs about zinc treatment after tha airing of a national mass-media campaign
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Over half (53.1%) of allcaregivers (n=3,550) interviewed had heard about zinc products; most (97.1%) of those who had heard of zinc knew that zinc should be used for the treatment of diarrhea

Behaviors: At follow-up, the majority (67.5%) of children (n=289), aged less than six years, with diarrhea were treated with ORS, and 15.4% were treated with zinc. Children whose caregivers recalled the mass-media message that zinc should be used for 10 days and whose caregivers perceived that zinc is easy to obtain were more likely to be treated with zinc for 10 days, along with ORS
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 5: Behavior, Theory, Customer orientation, Insight Mixed methods

Increasing equity of access to point-of-use water treatment products through social marketing and entrepreneurship: A case study in western Kenya

Freeman MC, Quick RE, Abbott DP, Ogutu P, Rheingans R
Journal of Water & Health, 2009, 7 (3): 527-534
Location Nyanza Province, Kenya
Population 487 randomly selected households in eight communities served by the women’s groups
Intervention Description Safe Water System is a simple, inexpensive, point-of-use (POU) household water quality intervention using: 1) locally produced sodium hypochloritesolution for water treatment; 2) safe storage with containerswith a narrow mouth, tight fitting lid and tap; and 3) behaviour change communications; women’s groups in western Kenya were trained toeducate neighbours and sell health products to generate income (PSI)
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Knowledge of water treatment products was high

Behaviors: 20% (range 5–39%) of households in eight communities purchased and used chlorine, as confirmed by residual chlorine observed in stored water
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria X: Exchange, Method mix

Bringing safe water to remote populations: An evaluation of a portable point-of-use intervention in rural Madagascar

Ram PK, Kelsey E, R, Miarintsoa RR, Rakotomalala O, Dunston C, Quick RE
American Journal of Public Health, 2007, 97 (3): 398-400
Location Tamatave Province, Madagascar
Population Respondents from 242 households in 4 villages were interviewed
Intervention Description Social marketing campaign to promote SWS and SurEau water disinfectant. Campaign used community based sales agents
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Respondents from 239 households (99%) had heard of Sûr’Eau, the SWS disinfectant

Behaviors: 226 (95%) reported having ever used Sûr’Eau, and 166 (73%) reported current use. Current Sûr’Eau use was confirmedin 54% of households
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 3
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 3: Behavior, Exchange, Methods mix

Acceptability of and adherence to dispersible zinc tablet in the treatment of acute childhood diarrhoea

Nasrin D, Larson, CP, Sultana S, Khan, TU
Journal of Health, Population, and Nutrition, 2005, 23 (3): 215-221
Location 4 sub-districts in Dhaka, Bangladesh
Population Children between the ages of 3 and 59 months and their caretakers
Intervention Description Distribution and sales of zinc tablets by a social marketing firm
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: The formulation was acceptable to children; 90.1% of 303 caretakers perceived that the tablets were equally or even more acceptable to their children compared to other medicines

Behaviors: Ninety-eight percent of the children received the standard dose of one tablet per day, 55.8% completed the full 10-day course of zinc treatment
Design Observational
Sampling Method Purposive
Strength of Evidence Score 3
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 1: Methods mix

Social marketing and motivational interviewing as community interventions for safe water behaviors: Follow-up surveys in Zambia

Thevos AK, Olsen SJ, Kaona FAD, Tembo M, Quick RE
International Quarterly of Community Health Education, 2002, 21 (1): 51-65
Location Ndola and Kitwe, Zambia
Population Peri-urban households
Intervention Description Volunteer community health promoters in experimental (social marketing + motivational interviewing) and comparison (social marketing only) groups trained in causes of diarrhea and prevention through use of Clorin and safe water storage by SFH/Zambia. Health promoters in experimental group additionally trained in MI techniques. After training, promoters conducted weekly household visits to promote and sell Clorin
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: At 3 mos FU, 68% of households in SM group knew of correct disinfectant use vs. 80% in SM+MI group (p>0.05). At 16 mos FU, 80% of households in SM group knew of correct disinfectant use vs. 89% in SM+MI group (p>0.05)

Behaviors: At 3 mos FU in Ndola,48% of households in SM group storing water safely vs. 87% in SM+MI group (p<0.01). At 16 mos FU in Kitwe, 63% of household in SM group stored water safely vs. 64% in SM+MI group (p>0.05)
Design Experimental
Sampling Method Probablity
Strength of Evidence Score 6
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 2: Behavior, Theory

Evidence of behaviour change following a hygiene promotion programme in Burkina Faso

Curtis V, Kanki B, Cousens S, Diallo I, Kpozehouen, Sangare M, Nikiema M
Bulletin of the World Health Organization, 2001, 79 (6): 518-27
Location Bobo-Dioulasso, Burkina Faso
Population Mothers ofchildren aged 0–35 months, older sisters, maids, and school-aged children
Intervention Description Social marketing campaign involving house-to-house visits, performance of plays, and school curriculum
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Improved knowledge

Behaviors: Safedisposal of children’s stools changed little between 1995 and 1998 (80% pre-intervention, 84% postintervention);hand-washing with soap after cleaning a child’s bottom rose from 13% to 31% and the proportion ofmothers who washed their hands with soap after using the latrine increased from 1% to 17%
Design Quasi-experimental
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 5
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 5: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Segmentation, Methods mix

Analysis of different communication channels for promoting hygiene behavior

Pinfold JV
Health Education Research, 1998, 14 (5): 629-639
Location Six sub-districts in Khon Kaen Province, Thailand
Population Households from selected villages and random selection of schools - study used questionnaires and focus group discussions
Intervention Description Social marketing campaign to improve hand and dish-washing practices. Campaign involved both a variety of media outlets as well as village-level health workers
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Strong correlation between number of communication channels remembered by respondents and knowledge

Behaviors: No significant improvements in behaviors outside of school children
Design Quasi-experimental
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 5
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Competition, Segmentation, Mixed methods
